newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo precious metals end firmer with New York.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo precious metals end firmer with New York.

text.p: Yen-based precious metal futures ended mostly higher on Friday in dull, rangebound trade, matching firmer levels reached overnight in New York but finding no follow-through buying, traders said.
The market also received no direction from the currency markets, with the yen holding steady against the dollar.
TOCOM most-active June 1997 gold settled four yen higher at 1,344 yen per gram, traded very narrowly from 1,345 to 1,343, while the remaining months finished one to three yen better.
Bullion settled at $387.50/80, fractionally above the New York closing quote of $387.20/70.

Gold prices strengthened overnight following cuts in money market rates in Germany and other European centres, although resistance above $388 was seen capping the market amid quiet summer trading. Traders pegged support at $385.50 to $386.
"If spot gold doesn't get above $389 today in New York, the outlook for near-term gains will not be very good," one trading house source said.
He added that overseas players appeared reluctant to take positions ahead of holidays Monday in Hong Kong and Britain.
Platinum and silver also ended higher in line with overnight gains.
Benchmark June 1997 platinum was up five yen at 1,381 yen per gram, while June 1997 silver rose 1.1 yen to 183.7 yen per 10 grams.
Only palladium was lower, reflecting weakness overnight as the market struggled to form a base after sliding to 2 1/2-year lows earlier this week.
June 1997 palladium ended three yen lower at 437 yen per gram, while the remaining months were three lower to one firmer.
